%%writefile my_code_test.c

#include <stdio.h>

int main (){


  int x = 5;
  int y = 2;
  float z = x / (float) y;
  printf("%f",z);


  return 0;
}
!gcc my_code_test.c -o my_c_program
!./my_c_program

ูุฎูุงู Devc++ ุฑู ูุตุจ ฺฉูู ู ุงูุทูุฑู ฺฉู: ูู ุงุฒ ูุดฺฉูุช ูุฑุงุฑ ูฺฉูโบ๏ธ
%%writefile adding_up.c

 #include <stdio.h>

int main () {
 int num, i, tmp;

 printf("enter a positive nomber n i will add up every nomber befor that together: ");
 scanf("%d", &num);

 tmp = num;
 i = 0;

 while (i <= num) {
  (num - i) + tmp = tmp;
  i++;
 }

 printf("%d", tmp);

 return 0;
}

 c
#include <stdio.h>

int pr(int);
int main() {
    int i, n, sum = 0;
    scanf("%d", &n);
    for (i = 2; i <= n; i++)
        if (pr(i) == 1)
            sum = sum + i;
    printf("\n%d", sum);
    return 0;
}

int pr(int x) {
    int i;
    for (i = 2; i < x; i++)
        if (x % i == 0)
            return 0;
    return 1;
}

ย localStorage.setItem('userCredentials', credentialsJSON);

From: Fleabag
Lacrimosa is a Latin word that translates to "weeping" or "tearful." It is often associated with mourning, sorrow, and lamentation, and is commonly used in the context of requiem masses and funeral music. In music, "Lacrimosa" is also the title of a famous movement in Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's Requiem Mass in D minor.

ุฏูุฏ ูู ู ูุดฺฉู ุฏุงุฑู ุจุง ุญูุด ฺฉูู
ุจฺฏู ุฌุงูู

#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
using namespace std;

// ุชุงุจุน ุจุงุฒฺฏุดุช ุจุฑุง ูพุฏุง ฺฉุฑุฏู ุฌูุช ุฎุงููโ ุฎุฑุงุจ
pair<int, int> find_corrupted_pair(const vector<int>& arr, int start, int end) {
    if (start >= end)
        return make_pair(-1, -1);

    int mid = (start + end) / 2;
    
    // ุจุฑุฑุณ ููู ฺูพ
    pair<int, int> left_corrupted = find_corrupted_pair(arr, start, mid);

    // ุจุฑุฑุณ ููู ุฑุงุณุช
    pair<int, int> right_corrupted = find_corrupted_pair(arr, mid + 1, end);

    // ุงฺฏุฑ ุฌูุช ุฎุงููโ ุฎุฑุงุจ ุฏุฑ ูุฑ ุฏู ููู ูพุฏุง ุดูุฏุ ุขู ุฑุง ุจุฑูโฺฏุฑุฏุงูู
    if (left_corrupted.first != -1)
        return left_corrupted;
    if (right_corrupted.first != -1)
        return right_corrupted;

    // ุงฺฏุฑ ฺฉ ุงุฒ ูููโูุง ุญุงู ุฌูุช ุฎุงููโ ุฎุฑุงุจ ุจุงุดุฏุ ุขู ุฑุง ุจุฑูโฺฏุฑุฏุงูู
    if (arr[mid] == arr[mid + 1])
        return make_pair(mid, mid + 1);
    
    // ุฏุฑ ุบุฑ ุงู ุตูุฑุชุ ููฺฉู ุงุณุช ุฌูุช ุฎุงููโ ุฎุฑุงุจ ุฏุฑ ุฏู ููู ุจุงุดุฏ ฺฉู ููุฏุงุฑ ุขููุง ุจุฑุงุจุฑ ุงุณุช
    for (int i = start; i <= mid; ++i) {
        if (arr[i] == arr[mid + 1])
            return make_pair(i, mid + 1);
    }

    // ุงฺฏุฑ ุฌูุช ุฎุงููโ ุฎุฑุงุจ ูพุฏุง ูุดุฏุ ุจุฑูโฺฏุฑุฏุงูู
    return make_pair(-1, -1);
}

int main() {
    // ุฎูุงูุฏู ุทูู ุขุฑุงู
    int n;
    cout << "Enter the size of the array: ";
    cin >> n;

    // ุฎูุงูุฏู ุนูุงุตุฑ ุขุฑุงู
    vector<int> arr(n);
    cout << "Enter the elements of the array (0 or 1): ";
    for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i)
        cin >> arr[i];

    // ุงูุชู ุฌูุช ุฎุงููโ ุฎุฑุงุจ
    pair<int, int> corrupted_pair = find_corrupted_pair(arr, 0, n - 1);

    // ฺุงูพ ุงูุฏุณโูุง ุฎุงููโูุง ุฎุฑุงุจ
    cout << "Corrupted indices: ";
    if (corrupted_pair.first != -1)
        cout << corrupted_pair.first << " " << corrupted_pair.second << endl;
    else
        cout << "No corrupted indices found." << endl;

    return 0;
}

ูููู ฺฉู ุฏุณฺฉุฑูพุดู ูพุฑุงูุณ ู ุณุฑ ฺฉุงุฑุงฺฉุชุฑ ูุญุฏูุฏ ุจุงุดู ุชุง ููุด ูููุน ููุงุด ุฌุง ุจุดู (ุงููุช ูู ุงููุฑุขู)*
ุงุตูุง ุงุถุทุฑุงุฑ ูุณุชู ู ูุฑุจูุท ุจู ุงูพู ู ุจุงุฏ ููุช ููุช ู ุญูุตูู ุฏุงุดุชู ุจูุดูู ฺฏูุด ุจุฏ.
The concept of frames per second (fps) in monitors goes beyond just what the human eye can perceive. While it's true that the human eye can generally perceive around 24-30 fps as smooth motion, higher frame rates like 60 fps or 120 fps offer benefits in certain situations:

1. Motion Smoothness: Higher frame rates make motion appear smoother, especially in fast-paced content like gaming or sports. This is because more frames per second provide more information about the motion, reducing motion blur and judder.

2. Responsiveness: Higher frame rates can improve the responsiveness of a monitor, which is crucial for gaming and other real-time applications. A higher refresh rate means the monitor can display new frames more quickly, reducing input lag.

3. Reduced Eye Strain: Some people find higher refresh rates more comfortable to view for extended periods, as they can reduce eye strain and fatigue, especially when dealing with fast-moving content.

4. Future-Proofing: Investing in a monitor with a higher refresh rate can also be seen as future-proofing. As content and technology evolve, higher refresh rates may become more standard, especially in gaming and multimedia applications.

However, whether these benefits are worth the cost depends on your specific use case and preferences. For casual use like web browsing and watching videos, a standard 60 Hz monitor may suffice. But for gaming, professional video editing, or if you simply prefer smoother motion, a higher refresh rate monitor like 120 Hz or more can offer tangible advantages.
